Description: East Greek terracotta figure vase (plastic vase). Complete small vase (apart from rim) in the form of head and shoulders of gorgoneion. She wears a headband in front of crudely depicted snakes, two of which rise to her chin. Her mouth is open with tongue thrust out between two long teeth sticking up from her mandible. She has almond shaped eyes. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of red paint on her 'hair'. White residue on her chin probably post depositional. Pale orange clay fabric with abundant silver mica, black and coarse white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ9(?) (?)
Curator's comments: Originally thought to be Rhodian (Higgins 1954, 46), though some of this Rhodian group have subsequently been found to be East Greek (Jones 1985, 673). Higgins cites 6th century BC parallels now in Florence and Rome (Maximova 1927, 163, 164). Chemical analysis (NAA), suggests a Samian origin. Jones, R. E. 1985. 'Greek and Cypriot Pottery: A Review of Scientific Studies'. Athens. Maximova, M. I. 1927. ‘Les vases plastiques dans l’antiquité’. Paris. Blinkenberg, C. 1931. ‘Lindos, Fouilles del'Acropole, 1902-14: Les Petits Objects’.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (52)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.018) (Phase 3)
